Kremlin website was down

The Kremlin Palace in Moscow, Russia.Jarung H/Shutterstock

The official website of the Kremlin, kremlin.ru, was down on Saturday, Reuters reported.

The outage came after Ukrainian Vice Prime Minister Mykhailo Fedorov said the country will create an ‚ÄúIT army‚Äù to fight against Russia‚Äôs digital intrusions.

In a tweet that linked to a channel on the Telegram messaging app, which published a list of prominent Russian websites, Fedorov said: ‚ÄúWe are creating an IT army. There will be tasks for everyone. We continue to fight on the cyber front. The first task is on the channel for cyber specialists.‚Äù

President Zelensky appeals for foreign volunteers to come to Ukraine and enlist in a ‚ÄòInternational Legion‚Äô

Ukraine President Volodymyr ZelenskyUkraine President Volodymyr Zelensky

Ukraine is establishing an International Legion for foreigners who want to come and fight against Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Sunday.

‚ÄúAnyone who wants to join the defense of Ukraine, Europe and the world can come and fight side by side with the Ukrainians against the Russian war criminals,‚Äù the statement on the presidential website said.

Zelensky called for international solidarity against Russia and said in the statement that Russia‚Äôs invasion was ‚Äúthe beginning of a war against Europe.‚Äù

Ukrainian border guards who told Russian warship ‚Äògo fuck yourself‚Äô may still be alive

Zmiinyi (Snake) Island is situated near the Ukrainian and Romanian coasts along the Black Sea.Google Maps

A group of 13 Ukrainian border guards who were thought to have been killed while defending an island from a Russian warship may still be alive, the State Border Guard Service of Ukraine (SBGSU) said in a statement on Saturday.

‚ÄúWe [have a] strong belief that all Ukrainian defenders of Zmiinyi (Snake) Island may be alive,‚Äù the border agency said.

‚ÄúPreliminary information that border guards may be dead came before the defenders lost contact,‚Äù it added.

The statement comes two days after reports said that 13 border guards on Zmiinyi Island had died when they refused to surrender to a Russian warship, telling it ‚Äúgo fuck yourself‚Äù per an audio recording.

Elon Musk says Starlink satellite service is activated in Ukraine

Elon Musk, Tesla CEOPatrick Pleul/picture alliance via Getty Images

SpaceX founder Elon Musk responded to pleas from a Ukrainian government official on Saturday, agreeing to send Starlink terminals to the country amid the Russian invasion that has disrupted internet services.

‚ÄúStarlink service is now active in Ukraine. More terminals en route,‚Äù Musk tweeted at Ukrainian Vice Prime Minister Mykhailo Fedorov.

Internet connectivity throughout Ukraine has been affected by the invasion, though the extent wasn‚Äôt immediately clear on Saturday.

In response to Musk‚Äôs announcement, the official Twitter account for Ukraine tweeted at Musk: ‚Äúthankx, appreciate it.‚Äù

Russian forces blew up a gas pipeline in Ukraine‚Äôs second-largest city, Kharkiv

Ukrainian soldiers handle equipment outside Kharkiv, Ukraine, Saturday, Feb. 26, 2022.AP Photo/Andrew Marienko

Ukrainian President Zelensky‚Äôs office said Russian forces blew up a gas pipeline in Kharkiv, the Associated Press reported.

Residents were advised to cover their windows with damp cloth or gauze and the Ukrainian government warned that smoke from the explosion in the country‚Äôs second-largest city could result in an ‚Äúenvironmental catastrophe,‚Äù the AP reported.

There are at least 240 civilian casualties so far, according to the UN

A Ukrainian soldier walks past debris of a burning military truck, on a street in Kyiv, Ukraine, Saturday, Feb. 26, 2022.AP Photo/Efrem Lukatsky

The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights reported that there have been at least 240 civilian casualties, including at least 64 deaths in Ukraine, since the start of Russia‚Äôs invasion.

Hundreds of homes have also been damaged, and the damage to infrastructure has left thousands without power or water, the OHCHR reported.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees also reported that over 160,000 people are internally displaced and more than 116,000 have fled to neighboring countries.

French President Emmanuel Macron called on Belarus to order Russian troops to leave

French President Emmanuel Macron meets Russian President Vladimir Putin on February 07, 2022 in Moscow, Russia.Getty Images

In a call on Saturday, French President Emmanuel Macron asked Alexander Lukashenko, the president of Belarus, to demand Russian troops be withdrawn from Belarusian soil, a statement from Macron‚Äôs office said.

Belarus is a neighbor to Ukraine and one of multiple entry points Russia used to invade the country.

Macron denounced ‚Äúthe seriousness of a decision that would authorize Russia to deploy nuclear weapons on Belarusian soil‚Äù and told Lukashenko that Belarus should ‚Äúrefuse to be Russia‚Äôs vassal and de facto accomplice in the war against Ukraine.‚Äù

Western nations agree to cut ‚Äòselected Russian banks‚Äô from the SWIFT global banking system

The United States, the European Union, the United Kingdom, and Canada struck an agreement Saturday evening to remove certain Russian banks from SWIFT.

SWIFT is a payment system that is crucial for global financial communication. Removing Russia from the system could be economically devastating for the nation.

In a joint statement, the US and its counterparts declared that the move would help ‚Äúcollectively ensure that this war is a strategic failure for Putin.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs Russian forces unleash their assault on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities, we are resolved to continue imposing costs on Russia that will further isolate Russia from the international financial system and our economies,‚Äù the statement said.

READ FULL STORY

Germany to send anti-tank weapons and missiles to Ukraine in a major policy reversal

Germany is planning to send 1,000 anti-tank weapons and 500 Stinger missiles to Ukraine, according to a statement made by German Chancellor Olaf Scholz on Saturday.

‚ÄúThe Russian attack marks a turning point,‚Äù Scholz wrote in a statement shared on Twitter. ‚ÄúIt is our duty to do our best to help Ukraine defend against the invading army of Putin. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre supplying 1000 anti-tank weapons and 500 stinger missiles to our friends in Ukraine.‚Äù

The announcement marks a significant shift of Germany‚Äôs restrictive arms export policy. The country has previously said it held ‚Äúhistorical responsibilities‚Äù that prevented it from sending weapons and arms to conflict areas, often citing guilt for crimes committed against the Soviet Union during World War II.

Read Full Story

Russian forces are ‚Äòfrustrated‚Äô with lack of progress, US official says

According to a Reuters report, the US official, who was not named by the outlet, said Russian forces had not planned to bring enough fuel or for other basic logistics.

‚ÄúWe know that they have not made the progress that they have wanted to make, particularly in the north. They have been frustrated by what they have seen is a very determined resistance,‚Äù the official told Reuters, adding: ‚ÄúIt has slowed them down.‚Äù

An unnamed US official told Fox News: ‚ÄúWe continue to believe, based on what we‚Äôve observed, that this resistance is greater than what the Russians expected.‚Äù

The British Defense Ministry on Saturday made similar claims, saying: ‚ÄúThe speed of the Russian advance has temporarily slowed likely as a result of acute logistical difficulties and strong Ukrainian resistance,‚Äù according to the Associated Press.

Zelensky called on ‚Äòevery friend of Ukraine‚Äô to ‚Äòplease come over‚Äô and help defend against Russian invasion

Ukraine President Volodymyr ZelenskyUkraine President Volodymyr Zelensky

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday remained defiant in the face of Russia‚Äôs invasion, confirming that government forces continued to control Kyiv and ‚Äúkey points around the city.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease stop those who are lying, or trying to lie to you, or lying to us. We need to stop this war,‚Äù he said during a morning briefing, The Guardian reported, lambasting disinformation about the state of the country. ‚ÄúWe can live in peace together, globally, as humans.‚Äù

He continued: ‚ÄúOur military, our national guard, our national police, our territory defense, special service, nationals of Ukraine, please carry on. We will win. Glory to Ukraine.‚Äù
